Dialogue.content: Hi, I'm Ava Johnson. It's nice to meet you.
Hello Ava! It's great to meet you too. How are you feeling with the new semester starting?
I'm really excited about my psychology classes, but I'm also feeling a bit overwhelmed.
That's understandable. What exactly is overwhelming you?
The course load is heavier than I expected, and I recently joined a volunteer group focusing on mental health awareness.
It sounds like you have a lot on your plate. Have you been able to manage your time effectively?
Not really. I'm worried I won't keep up and will let my peers down.
It's normal to feel that way, especially when you want to make a positive impact. Have you considered prioritizing your commitments?
I haven't made a solid plan yet. I just feel anxious about everything.
Creating a plan might help reduce that anxiety. Could you try listing out your tasks and see what can be prioritized?
That makes sense. I'll give that a try.
Good idea! And remember, it's also important to take breaks and practice self-care. What do you enjoy doing for fun?
I love dancing and photography, but I haven't had much time for those lately.
Those activities can be great stress relievers. Maybe you can schedule short breaks for them? It could help you recharge.
I will definitely try that. Thank you for your suggestions!
You're welcome, Ava! It's great that you're acknowledging your feelings. Let's reconvene next week to see how you're doing.
Hi Counselor, it's me, Ava again. I'm feeling even more stressed this week.
Hi Ava! I'm sorry to hear that. What's been causing the increase in stress?
Midterms are coming up, and I'm struggling to keep up with everything. During a meeting for my volunteer group, I shared my concerns, but it didn't go well.
That sounds difficult. What happened during the meeting?
Some people were supportive, but others dismissed my feelings. It left me feeling frustrated and isolated.
It's tough to feel unsupported, especially when you're opening up. How did that affect you afterward?
I felt like my emotions weren't valued, and now I'm doubting myself and my contributions.
Those feelings are completely valid. Maybe it would help to talk to someone who is supportive? Have you thought about reaching out to a trusted friend?
I'm hesitant because I don't want to burden them.
Reaching out can actually strengthen relationships; your friends might want to support you. Would you consider it?
I think I should try. I just don't know how to start the conversation.
You could start by sharing that you are having a tough time and would appreciate their support. Simple and honest can be powerful.
That sounds doable. I'll try to talk to them soon. Thank you for understanding!
Hey, it's Ava. I'm really struggling this week.
Hi Ava, I'm glad you're here. What's been going on?
Midterms are next week, and I received some negative feedback on a paper that hit me hard.
I'm really sorry to hear that. How did you react to the feedback?
It made me feel defeated, especially with everything else I'm dealing with. During a project meeting, I confronted a classmate, Alex, who was dismissive of my ideas.
That sounds like a tough situation. Confrontations can be really stressful. How did it feel afterward?
I felt shaky and conflicted. I'm questioning my worth in both the project and my friendships.
It's common to feel that way after a conflict. It might help to reflect on what was said and how you want to communicate your feelings moving forward.
I just want harmony. I didn't mean to create tension.
Acknowledging your feelings is important. Would it be helpful to have a follow-up conversation with Alex to clarify things?
Maybe, but I'm worried it will lead to more conflict.
Approaching it with the intent to understand and convey your feelings could create a more constructive dialogue. You have the ability to advocate for yourself.
That gives me some hope. I want to work on that.
Hi, Counselor! I finally spoke with Dr. Brown about everything.
Hi Ava! I'm glad to see you. How did that conversation go?
It felt good to open up about my pressures and feelings of inadequacy. Dr. Brown provided some excellent advice.
That's fantastic! What kind of advice did they give you?
They emphasized the importance of self-care and helped me learn how to set boundaries. I feel a little more equipped to handle everything.
That sounds great! How do you plan to move forward from here?
I want to express my concerns to my project group and ensure they understand how I feel.
That's a brave step! How are you feeling about having that conversation now?
I'm still a bit anxious, but I also feel hopeful. Addressing this could really help resolve some tension.
Hope is a powerful motivator! Have you found time to enjoy your hobbies during this process?
Yes! I went dancing last weekend, and it felt amazing. I need to remember to prioritize that.
Absolutely! Maintaining your interests can be therapeutic. I'm really proud of you for the progress you've made.
Thank you! I really appreciate your support throughout this journey. I'll see you next time!
